text: heatmaps visualize dependence across quantiles changes S&P 500 gold bitcoin — revealing whether gold/bitcoin remains uncorrelated negatively correlated (safe haven) market stress.
code: ## Install the 'quantilogram' library # install.packages("quantilogram")  library(quantilogram) # Use gold (GLD) as predicted variable, S&P (SP) as predicting variable df1 <- hedgedata[, c("GLD", "SP")] ## setup and estimation  k = 1                             ## lag order  vec.q  = seq(0.05, 0.95, 0.05)    ## a list of quantiles  B.size = 100                      ## Repetition of bootstrap   res1 = crossq.heatmap(df1, k, vec.q, B.size, var1_name = "Gold", var2_name = "SP500")   ## result  print(res1$plot) # Use bitcoin (BTC) as predicted variable, S&P (SP) as predicting variable df2 <- hedgedata[, c("BTC", "SP")] res2 = crossq.heatmap(df2, k, vec.q, B.size, var1_name = "Bitcoin", var2_name = "SP500")   ## result  print(res2$plot)

title: Conditional Diversification Benefit (CDB) — cdb
text: function computes $$ \mathrm{CDB}(w,p) = \frac{ w\,\mathrm{ES}_X(p) + (1-w)\,\mathrm{ES}_Y(p) - \mathrm{ES}_P(p) }                                    { w\,\mathrm{ES}_X(p) + (1-w)\,\mathrm{ES}_Y(p) - \mathrm{VaR}_P(p) } $$ ES VaR computed via cvar::ES() cvar::VaR() using stats::qnorm (normal approximation). Portfolio mean/SD use plug-means/SDs independence assumption (covariance term).

title: Daily log returns for S&P 500, Bitcoin, and Gold — hedgedata
text: Data construction process dataset created using following R workflow:   Log returns computed \(\log(P_t / P_{t-1})\). Data daily aligned calendar date. Missing values (due non-trading days) left NA na.omit().
code: library(quantmod) library(zoo)  symbols <- c("^GSPC", "BTC-USD", "GC=F") names_vec <- c("SP", "BTC", "GLD")  from <- as.Date("2015-01-01") to <- Sys.Date()  # Download daily closing prices get_close <- function(sym, from, to) {   x <- getSymbols(sym, src = "yahoo", from = from, to = to, auto.assign = FALSE)   Cl(x) }  prices <- do.call(merge, lapply(symbols, get_close, from = from, to = to)) colnames(prices) <- names_vec  # Compute daily log returns hedgedata <- diff(log(prices)) hedgedata <- na.omit(hedgedata)  # Save into package usethis::use_data(hedgedata, overwrite = TRUE)

title: Hedge Ratio, Hedging Effectiveness, and Optimal Hedging Weight — hedge_effectiveness_dcc
text: one-row data.frame : beta_mean Mean hedge ratio \(\bar{\beta}\) beta_min Minimum hedge ratio beta_max Maximum hedge ratio Single conditional hedging effectiveness value OPW Mean optimal portfolio weight hedging asset (clipped)

title: Hedge Ratio, Hedging Effectiveness, and Optimal Hedging Weight — hedge_effectiveness_dcc
text: Let \(\Sigma_t\) conditional covariance matrix DCC fit elements \(\Sigma_{11,t} = \sigma^2_{1,t}\), \(\Sigma_{22,t} = \sigma^2_{2,t}\), \(\Sigma_{12,t}\). time-varying hedge ratio $$\beta_t = \Sigma_{12,t} / \Sigma_{22,t}.$$ conditional hedging effectiveness () reported single value: $$\;=\; 1 - \frac{\overline{\operatorname{Var}_t(y_1 - \beta_t y_2)}}%                         {\overline{\sigma^2_{1,t}}}      \;=\; 1 - \frac{\overline{\sigma^2_{1,t} - \Sigma_{12,t}^2/\sigma^2_{2,t}}}                         {\overline{\sigma^2_{1,t}}},$$ bar denotes time average. optimal portfolio weight hedged/spot asset \(S\) versus hedging asset \(F\) follows: $$w_{SF,t} \;=\; \frac{\sigma^2_{F,t} - \Sigma_{SF,t}}                            {\sigma^2_{S,t} - 2\Sigma_{SF,t} + \sigma^2_{F,t}},$$ clipped \([0,1]\). function returns OPW mean weight hedging asset, .e. \(\overline{1 - w_{SF,t}}\).

title: Regression Coefficient Estimation (Baur & McDermott, 2010) — hedge_safehaven_bm10
text: Estimates time‐varying hedge ratio tail behavior following model Baur & McDermott (2010): $$ \begin{aligned} r_{\mathrm{Gold},t} &= + b_t r_{\mathrm{Stock},t} + e_t \quad &(1a)\\ b_t &= c_0 + c_1 D(r_{\mathrm{Stock},q_{10}}) + c_2 D(r_{\mathrm{Stock},q_{5}}) + c_3 D(r_{\mathrm{Stock},q_{1}}) \quad &(1b)\\ h_t &= \pi + \alpha e_{t-1}^2 + \beta h_{t-1} \quad &(1c) \end{aligned} $$ \(r_{\mathrm{Gold},t}\) return hedging asset (e.g., gold), \(r_{\mathrm{Stock},t}\) return market (hedged) asset, \(D(r_{\mathrm{Stock},q_i})\) dummy equal 1 market return lies \(\%\) quantile.
